bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, March 25, 1902
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D APR 02 DEPT OF STATE

div1.p: No. 89 fes. Consular, Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, March 25, 1902.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. The return of the original papers in the Aramers M. Miller estate claim for $456.59..
No. 89 fis, Consular Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, March 25, 1902
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor, according to your dispatch No. 29, of December 31, 1900, to return, herewith to you the original papers transmitted to this Consulat General, by the State Department, in your dispatch No. 29, of December 31, 1900, for use as evidence, if necessary, in the claim of Miss Winifred Miller, of New Castle, MO him at law, of the estate of the late Aramnus M. Miller for

for Four Hundred, Fiftey-six, 59/100 Dollars, against the Liberian Government, for the redemption of Four Hundred, Fifty-six 59/100 Dollars in Liberia Scrip, Government Bills or its circulating medium. I have to say that notwithstanding, I have been able to serve a promise fromsaid Government, February 8, 1901, that it would reduce said scrip, Government Bills or circulating medium, and that the said Government has through the action of its Secretary of the Treasury Hon. Arthur Barclay, accepted an Order upon him to pay me said amount, yet I have this far been unable to collect but 14 cents only of said claim. The papers
papers I now return with this dispatch, but the accepted order, I will hold until I return to Washington.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
